Description: Small jar with restricted mouth, made from Nile silt fired to a red-brown colour. The surface is untreated, and bears the marks from organic temper burnt out during the firing process.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Umm el-Qaab (Abydos), This vessel was found amongst the mass of New Kingdom and later offering pottery deposited at Umm el-Qa'ab, attesting to the interpretation of the Early Dynastic cemetery as the tomb of Osiris, and its long-term use as a focus for cult.
Curator's comments: Naville, Cemeteries I, 38, pl.XV, 6. For coarse drop-shaped from Tell el-Amarna, see P. Rose, The Eighteenth Dynasty Pottery Corpus from Amarna (MEES 83, London, 2007): 237 [383]. See pp.98-100 and 241 for coarse 'beer-jars' from the same site, typically larger than this example.
